children.subject: CS 161 is very useful and helpful for good industry practices, and is pretty interesting. I highly recommend all CS majors take it.

Do you think its a good idea to take 174 P/NP? Like my schedule next spring would be 189 (with Professor Shewchuk), physics 7B, 161, and then 174 p/np? It'll probably be my last semester, and I think probabilistic algorithms are pretty cool, but I'm most likely not doing a research or theory job.

In general, I don't like to P/NP technical classes. A better alternative would be reading the textbook over the summer or whenever. Taking a course to me has the benefit of: Receiving credit in terms of a letter grade, better learning environment with TAs and Lectures, and peers to learn from. If you were to P/NP it, it may be more worthwhile to read the really good textbook.

I took both CS161 and CS174 this semester, and my perspective is pretty biased, because I enjoy 174 theory type material more. In terms of workload, they are about the same, but the type of work differs. 174 weekly psets took me around 5 hours a week, and 161 courseload is pretty light, except for the gargantuan project 2, which spanned about a month, and consisted of 3 subparts, which was horrible(but rewarding). For interesting-ness, I would go with 174 just because I love reading about graph random walks, cover times, probabilistic 2-sat algorithms etc., but the material in 161 was interesting as well if you invest yourself in learning it(I did not :P). For logistics, 161 is better organized by a landslide, as 174 only had around 50 students, and 1 gsi. I've heard that recent iteration of 161 has been harder than semesters past. As for 174, if Friedman is teaching it, the lectures are somewhat dry/slow so definitely get comfortable with the textbook. And the quality of discussion will depend on who the gsi is(mine was meh). For usefulness in industry, you could argue that 174 goes over pagerank, but applications in industry are far less ubiquitous than the concepts in 161. There are definitely applications of 174 in industry, but the topics are very lofty and high level, such as probabilistic 2-sat algorithms, and I would have preferred to have done some implementations/labs of the algorithms. 

Conclusion(My opinion): Of course it depends on why you want to take 174, but 161 wins in most of the criteria you listed.

How difficult are the exams and other parts of the class? I honestly just want to learn the material and have a strong algorithmic probability intuition. If I took the class P/NP would it be a significant add-on to the semester?

Can't speak to 161 but this semester I did 174 along with 189, Physics 7A and an R1B (so a very similar schedule to what you propose) and it was doable, but busy. Workload was 189 >>>>> 7A > 174. 5 hours a week is a good estimate of the time spent on p-sets.

history.content: I'm planning out next year's schedule, and I was wondering if anyone had any insight on which of these two classes I should take (next spring). I will likely be taking only one of them with CS 189 and physics 7B. What's the comparative workload of the two, and can anyone who's taken either (or preferably both) share their experience (usefulness in industry, logistics, interestingness)?
history.subject: CS 174 vs CS 161
